fields.descriptive_line: Wheel lock gun, French, from the Cabinet d'Armes of Louis XIII of France, 1575-1600
fields.physical_description: The half-length stock is of pear wood with iron mounts. The lock is of French construction finely chiselled, the pyrites holder in the form of a dragon, the rear part of the lock-plate in the form of a boar's head. The barrel is Turkish, of round section at the breech, polygonal along the rest of its length. The junction between the two sections is marked by a panel of conventional foliage chiselled in the thickness of the barrel. The muzzle is tulip shaped set with two silver rings. It is equipped with an aperture rear-sight and blade foresight. The ramrod, entirely of wood, fits loosely in its slot and is probably a restoration.
fields.dimensions: Length: 182.8 cm full, Length: 147.3 cm barrel, Height: 14.9 cm, Depth: 9.3 cm
fields.materials_techniques: Iron barrle, carved pearwood with iron mounts
fields.marks:
Segment of a circle, probably part of the number 3
 MA 775  Museum of Artillery Inventory Number
fields.public_access_description:
Arms and armour are rarely associated with art. However, they were influenced by the same design sources as other art forms including architecture, sculpture, goldsmiths' work, stained glass and ceramics. These sources had to be adapted to awkwardly shaped devices required to perform complicated technical functions. Armour and weapons were collected as works of art as much as military tools.

This wheel-lock gun has a mechanism that enabled it to be carried loaded. The jaws of the lock clamped a piece of flint or a piece or pyrites designed to rub against the rough edge of the wheel projecting into the pan. The wheel was revolved at speed by a tightly coiled spring, wound by a separate spanner, and released when the gun's trigger was pulled causing sparks to ignite the gunpowder in the breech.

Sketches for wheel-locks were made by Leonardo da Vinci but their first common use was in Germany in around 1520 and they continued in use until the late seventeenth century. They were the first devices to fire guns mechanically and accelerated the development of firearms by negating the need for long and dangerous 'match' cords which had to be kept dry. 

As technical devices wheel-lock guns attracted princely collectors. Many are finely chiselled and engraved as works of art, some even on their insides, to be taken apart and reassembled at pleasure. The stocks were also often decorated with fine bone and horn inlays drawing on the skills of furniture makers and engravers. Wheel-lock guns were expensive, however, and most ordinary gunners were equipped with the older style match-locks until well into the seventeenth century.
fields.bibliography:
Hayward, J. F., <u>European Firearms</u>. London, HMSO, 1969, 30
A guide to the Museum Collection of firearms first published in 1955. This edition includes a large number of illustrations and a complete text revision. The items described have been selected on the grounds of artistic merit and technical or historical interest.
fields.credit: Transferred from the Rotunda Museum of Artillery
fields.history_note:
From the Cabinet d'Armes of Louis XIII, King of France. Transferred from the Rotunda Museum of Artillery

This is one of the firearms brought to England from Paris as Trophies of War after the Battle of Waterloo. Though the inventory number is not clearly visible on the stock, this gun is typical of the firearms of Louis XIII, particularly as regards the stocking.

Historical significance: In view of its provenance, the Paris Arsenal, there appears to be no reason to doubt its attribution to the personal collection of Louis XIII.
